Container.Name: CrashPlan
Container.Overview: CrashPlan makes it easy to protect your digital life, so you can get back to what’s important in real life. Only CrashPlan offers totally free local and offsite backup. A subscription to the cloud backup service gets you continuous backup, mobile file access and lots more. For the ultimate in computer backup, get all three, from the same easy application. [br][br] The GUI of the application is accessed through a modern web browser (no installation or configuration needed on client side) or via any VNC client. Also, being based on Alpine Linux, size of this container is very small (less than 160MB in download size). [br][br][span][/span] For a complete documentation of this container, see [a href="https://github.com/jlesage/docker-crashplan/blob/master/README.md"] https://github.com/jlesage/docker-crashplan/blob/master/README.md[/a]. [br][br] [span style='color: red;'][b]Warning:[/b][/span] Make sure to read the [i]Taking Over Existing Backup[/i] section from the documentation if you are installing this container to replace another CrashPlan installation (from Windows, Linux, Mac or even another Docker container).

Container.Changes:
[font size=4][center]CrashPlan Change Log[/center][/font] [font size=3][b]v1.5.4[/b][/font] (2017-12-14) - Fixed an issue where the CrashPlan UI would not connect to the engine using the loopback IP. - Fixed an issue where automatic update could be partially done when running the container as root.
[font size=3][b]v1.5.3[/b][/font] (2017-12-12) - Now using baseimage v3.1.4, which brings the following changes: - Set 2 worker processes for nginx.
[font size=3][b]v1.5.2[/b][/font] (2017-11-20) - Now using baseimage v3.1.3, which brings the following changes: - Upgraded S6 overlay to version 1.21.2.1.
[font size=3][b]v1.5.1[/b][/font] (2017-11-07) - Now using baseimage v3.1.2, which brings the following changes (from last used version): - Fixed an issue where a self-disabled service could be restarted. - Upgraded S6 overlay to version 1.21.2.0. - Use a more efficient way to monitor status files. - Wait for the CrashPlan engine to be ready before starting the UI.
[font size=3][b]v1.5.0[/b][/font] (2017-10-30) - Now using baseimage v3.1.0, which brings the following changes: - Upgraded S6 overlay to version 1.21.1.1. - Enhanced integration of service dependencies functionality. - Added a simple log monitor. - Fixed race condition where container's exit code would not be the expected one. - Fixed issue where application's GUI fails to displayed when accessing it through the web interface via standard ports 80/443. - Now using the log monitor from the baseimage.
[font size=3][b]v1.4.2[/b][/font] (2017-10-09) - Now using baseimage v3.0.2, which brings the following changes: - Fixed issue where nginx config change was not applied correctly on systems without IPV6 support and secure connection disabled.
[font size=3][b]v1.4.1[/b][/font] (2017-10-08) - Now using baseimage v3.0.1, which brings the following changes: - Fixed nginx config for systems without IPV6 support.
[font size=3][b]v1.4.0[/b][/font] (2017-10-08) - Now using baseimage v3.0.0, which brings the following changes: - Better support for service dependencies. - Added support for secure access to the application's GUI.
[font size=3][b]v1.3.6[/b][/font] (2017-09-08) - Now using baseimage v2.0.8, which brings the following changes (from last used version): - Fixed timezone support on alpine-glibc images. - Fixed duplicated entries in /etc/passwd and /etc/group that were created after a restart of the container.
[font size=3][b]v1.3.5[/b][/font] (2017-08-14) - Now using baseimage v2.0.6, which brings the following changes: - Upgraded S6 overlay to version 1.20.0.0.
[font size=3][b]v1.3.4[/b][/font] (2017-07-31) - Now using baseimage v2.0.5, which brings the following changes (from last used version): - Clear the environment of the container during startup. - Clear the /tmp folder during startup. - Cleanly terminate the X server when container is restarted/stopped. - Improved robustness of X server starting process. - Removed unneeded files from the image.
[font size=3][b]v1.3.3[/b][/font] (2017-07-27) - Now using baseimage v2.0.3, which brings the following changes: - Improved robustness of the X server starting process.
[font size=3][b]v1.3.2[/b][/font] (2017-07-23) - Now using baseimage v2.0.2, which brings the following changes: - Proper VNC port is exposed.
[font size=3][b]v1.3.1[/b][/font] (2017-07-18) - Now using baseimage v2.0.1, which brings the following changes: - Internal enhancements. - Clean temporary files left by npm. - Fixed usage of unRAID notification system.
[font size=3][b]v1.3.0[/b][/font] (2017-07-17) - Now using baseimage v2.0.0, which brings the following changes: - Various internal enhancements. - Fixed the way a service waits for another one.
[font size=3][b]v1.2.0[/b][/font] (2017-07-05) - Report common CrashPlan issues/problems. When one is detected: - A message is sent to the main container's log. - A notification is sent via the unRAID's notification system (if supported). - Now using baseimage v1.5.0, which brings the following changes: - Added the UMASK environment variable to control how file permissions are set for newly created files. - Added the X11VNC_EXTRA_OPTS environment variable used to pass additional arguments to the x11vnc server. - By default, activate auto-scaling of application's window. - Applied latest Alpine Linux security updates.
[font size=3][b]v1.1.1[/b][/font] (2017-06-22) - Now using baseimage v1.4.3, which brings the following changes: - Updated Alpine Linux to version 3.6.2.
[font size=3][b]v1.1.0[/b][/font] (2017-06-21) - Now using baseimage v1.4.2, which brings the following changes (from last used version): - Switched to Alpine Linux 3.6. - Associate the application's icon to a unique version to avoid browser cache issues. - Fixed prefix of some service related messages. - Added support for supplying supplementary groups of the application. - Improved process startup and shutdown. - When container is stopped or restarted, processes are now terminated gracefully and in proper order. This allow the GUI application to execute its termination routine. - No more error messages when container is stopped or restarted.
[font size=3][b]v1.0.2[/b][/font] (2017-06-19) - Upgraded CrashPlan to version 4.8.3.
[font size=3][b]v1.0.1[/b][/font] (2017-05-30) - Now using baseimage v1.3.2, which brings the following changes: - Fixed password modal window not showing up when required. - Maximum amount of memory used by the CrashPlan Engine can now be set via the CRASHPLAN_SRV_MAX_MEM environment variable.
[font size=3][b]v1.0.0[/b][/font] (2017-05-29) - Initial release.

Config.Name: Config Directory
Config.Description: This is where the application stores its configuration, log and any files needing persistency.<br>Container path: /config

Config.Name: Storage
Config.Description: This location contains files from your host that need to be accessible by the application.<br>Container path: /storage

Config.Name: Flash
Config.Description: This is where data on your unRAID flash device is located. Useful to backup your unRAID configuration.<br>Container path: /flash

Config.Name: Inbound Backup Directory
Config.Description: This is where inboud backup archives are stored.<br>Container path: /backupArchives<br><b>NOTE:</b> This volume mapping is not needed if computer-to-computer backup feature is not used.

Config.Name: unRAID States
Config.Description: This is where unRAID state files are located. This is used by the container to generate unRAID notifications about common CrashPlan issues.<br>Container path: /var/local/emhttp

Config.Name: User ID
Config.Description: ID of the user the application runs as.

Config.Name: Group ID
Config.Description: ID of the group the application runs as.

Config.Name: Umask
Config.Description: Mask that controls how file permissions are set for newly created files. The value of the mask is in octal notation.

Config.Name: Niceness (priority)
Config.Description: Priority at which the application should run. A niceness value of -20 is the highest priority and 19 is the lowest priority.<br><b>NOTE:</b> Setting a negative value requires additional permissions. Thus, <i><b>--cap-add=SYS_NICE</b></i> must be added in <i>Extra Parameters</i> (shown when <i>Advanced View</i> is enabled).

Config.Name: Display Width
Config.Description: Width (in pixels) of the application's window.

Config.Name: Display Height
Config.Description: Height (in pixels) of the application's window.

Config.Name: Secure Connection
Config.Description: Whether or not an encrypted connection should be used to access the application's GUI. Set to <i><b>1</b></i> to encrypt the connection.<br><span style='color: red;'><b>Note:</b></span> When enabling the secure connection, security parameters needs to be generated. This <b>one-time</b> operation is done during container startup. Depending on your system, this could take a few minutes. GUI of the application won't be available until the operation completes.

Config.Name: Extra x11vnc Options
Config.Description: Extra options to pass to the x11vnc server running in the Docker container.<br><span style='color: red;'><b>Warning:</b></span> For advanced users. Do not use unless you know what you are doing.

Config.Name: Maximum Memory
Config.Description: Maximum amount of memory the CrashPlan Engine is allowed to use. One of the following memory unit (case insensitive) should be added as a suffix to the size: <b><i>G</i></b>, <b><i>M</i></b> or <b><i>K</i></b>. By default, when this variable is not set, a maximum of 1024MB (<b><i>1024M</i></b>) of memory is allowed.

Config.Name: WEB Port for GUI
Config.Description: Port used to access the application's GUI via the web interface.

Config.Name: VNC Port for GUI
Config.Description: Port used to access the application's GUI via the VNC protocol. Optional if no VNC client is used.

Config.Name: WEB Port for GUI
Config.Description: Port used for computer-to-computer backup.<br><b>NOTE:</b> To receive backups from remote computers over the internet, make sure to properly configure port-forwarding on your router.<br><b>NOTE:</b> This port mapping is not needed if computer-to-computer backup feature is not used.
